The EPA's RMP Comp (Version 1.07) was utilized to model the worst case scenario using the program's data elements to determine the distance to toxic end point.  No passive mitigation factors were considered for the worst-case scenario analysis.  Administrative controls, operating procedures, and design for the process limit the number of containers that can be connected to the process at any given time.  Thus, the worst-case scenario considers the maximum contents of one full container.

Population estimates within the toxic end point (3.0 miles) were obtained using the RTK NET Landview 5 program (Version 1.0) and were confirmed using St. Charles County's census data and population density information.

An alternate release scenario was also developed to model a more realistic release than the worst-case scenario such as releases from joints, flanges, elbows, weld points, valves and other vessel appurtenances.

The following information summarizes and documents an alternate release scenario for the facility:

Scenario: A tubing or valve and yoke assembly connection fails releasing liquid chlorine into the chlorine storage room floor from a horizontal 2,000 pound container.  The entire contents of the tank leaks onto the floor of the storage room floor forming a pool and begins to vaporize.  The release is a two-phase release occurring from a 5/16-inch diameter valve body opening.  The EPA's Off-site Consequence Analysis Guidance document was utilized to determine the alternative release scenario using the following standard assumptions:

The ambient relative humidity is 50%.

The ambient temperature of the surrounding air an

d the temperature of the chemical before the release is 77 degrees F (25 degrees C).

The facility is located in a rural area.

The wind speed is 3.0 meters per second at 10.0 meters above the ground.

The atmospheric stability is Class D (moderate wind speed and overcast skies).

The release occurs at different elevations relative to the ground.

The model determines the extent of the liquid evaporation at the source for liquefied gases.

Passive building mitigation factor of 55%.

The distance to the toxic end point (1.0 miles) for the alternative case release scenario was estimated using the EPA's Supplemental Risk Management Program Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants (July, 2004) utilizing the program's data elements, applicable look-up tables, equations, and formulas.

At atmospheric pressure and ambient temperatures, chlorine displays a greenish-yellow color.  In a gaseous state it is approximately 2.5 times heavier than air and will sink and conform to the contour of the ground in low lying areas.  As the gas spreads, it will become diluted with air depending on weather conditions, wind speed, humidity, etc.  As the gas becomes more diluted it will become neutrally bouyant and begin to travel with the main air streams.

This effect is particularly important to the PWSD #2 Water Plant because it is situated in a low lying area relative to the terrain immediately surronding the area.  It should be noted that the modeling programs and equations used to perform the worst-case and alternative release scenarios do not account for the extreme topography associated with the location of the facility.  Even if there is a prevailing cross-wind, the chlorine gas may tend to follow a depression due to its density.

The St. Charles County Hazardous Materials Response Plan has therefore been incorporated into the PWSD #2 Water Plant RMP by reference and recognized as part of the emergency action plan (EAP) for this facility.

In addition, The St. Charles County Standard Operating Procedure for E.O.C. Assistance (January, 2004) is also incorporated by reference into the RMP for weather and other natural disasters which could potentially cause a release of a regulated substance.

The Water Plant Supervisor and the District Manager will ensure that the emergency response team is adequately staffed and that the required equipment is supplied and maintained.  The Supervisor will coordinate with the local emergency planning committee (LEPC), local fire department, and hazardous material teams.  It is the intention of the PWSD #2 Water Plant to conduct regular emergency response drills with local emergency responders in an effort to coordinate effective and safe responses in the event of an actual release.

Emergency evacuation procedures, guidelines, and assembly areas have been established.  For minor releases, the initial assembly area will be the Control Room.  For a major release and evacuation, the initial assembly point shall be at the front gate entrance to the facility.  Emergency phone lists for all plant personnel are also maintained and posted at the facility.

The RMP program contains procedures for maintaining and performing the five-year accident history as required by the EPA.  Currently, there are no accidental release which have occurred within the past five years which resulted in any on-site or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, or environmental damage, etc. from this facility.

The integrated effect of the RMP program will have a proactive effect in reducing the risk of a release along with an increase in the safety of the public and the environment.

Saint Charles County Public Water Supply District #2 Water Plant
Risk Management Plan
Executive Summary

The goal of the Risk Management Program (RMP) is to reduce and prevent the risk of exposure of employees, the public, and the environment to the accidental release of chemicals used in the treatment of the potable water supply.  PWSD #2 and its employees are committed to achieving this goal through the implementation of the Risk Management Program.  The benefits of this program are intended to provide a safer workplace for employees and a safer environment for the community.

Because PWSD#2 exceeds the Environmental Protection Agency's threshold of 2,500 pounds, a Program 3level RMP has been developed to meet regulatory requirements.  Procedures for implementing and maintaining the RMP program are contained within this document.

The Water Plant Supervisor along with the assistance of the District Manager have the primary responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the RMP program.

The facility provides potable water to customers throughout St. Charles County.  The Facility consists of a well field of nine wells, a single-stage water softening treatment plant and approximately 8.0 million gallons of finished water storage.  The plant has a water supply capacity of approximately 22.4 million gallons per day.

The subject of the PWSD #2 Water Plant Risk Management Plan involves the use and storage of hazardous chemicals involved in the water treatment and disinfection process.  Currently, chlorine is the only chemical being stored and used in excess of the threshold quantity for chlorine in accordance with Section 112A® of the Clean Air Act.

Chlorine is a Toxic gas which is stored as a liquid under pressure.  The Maximum intended inventory at any given time that the plant could store is approximately 16,000 pounds.  Chlorine is irritating and corrosive to the eyes, skin, and respiratory tract and reacts violently with easily oxidi

zed materials.  Contact with evaporating chlorine or equipment releasing flashing chlorine can cause severe frostbite burns.  Chlorine gas is heavier than air and will tend to travel along the ground topography filling spaces, pits, and displacing breathable air.  Chlorine is also highly toxic to aquatic life.  The chlorine storage area for this facility is located in a separate storage building adjacent to areas of normal operating personnel.

Chlorine gas is injected in to the water at the hydrotreator, pre-filtration, and post-filtration stages in the process to chemically disinfect along with other water treatment chemicals prior to distribution into the public water supply system.  The chlorine is delivered to the process from 2,000 pound steel containers via a regulated vacuum system which allows operators of the system to control the rate of flow of chlorine into the water system.

In Accordance with CFR Part 68, an Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) has been performed to determine and document the facilities RMP program eligibility and to meet the EPA hazard assesment requirements for the applicable program.This OCA defines the toxic end point in all directions for worst-case and alternative release scenarios based on the applicable EPA guidance documents, modeling software, current available U.S. Census Bureau data, and available mapping tools.  Mapping and census figures from St. Charles County were also used to determine the population that would be affected in worst-case and alternate release scenarios.  The quantity of the hazardous substance, release rate, release duration, wind class and speed, topography and physical properties of the chemical are used to determine the distance to the toxic end point for the chemical and the public/environmental receptors which may be affected.

Chlorine for the facility is transported and stored in a liquid state under pressure.  When a leak occurs in a container or piping system, the quick reduction in pressure that occurs would cause the liquid chlorine to vaporize as it is released into the atmosphere.  The remainder of the liquid would pool and vaporize as it is warmed by environmental conditions.  When chlorine changes state from a liquid to a vapor, it expands to approximately 450 times the liquid volume.  Therefore, a release of chlorine liquid poses a significantly greater risk than a chlorine gas leak from a similar d vessel, pipe, or leak point.

It is the intention of the PWSD #2 Water Plant to minimize or eliminate the risk of an accidental release of a hazardous substance by utilizing the RMP program as a managerial tool to maintain and improve its internal operations, maintenance, and training programs which already currently exist.

The PWSD #2 Water Plant has developed an Emergency Response Program as part of the RMP program.  The purpose of this ensures that the PWSD  #2 Water Plant maintains current and complete written emergency action plans (EAP's) and effective response capabilities for all RMP covered processes.  The EAP, combined with effective emergency response drills and training, will hopefully minimize the impact of an accidental release by ensuring that the facility has a quick, well-organized response.  Currently the scope of the plan only includes releases of liquid chlorine, chlorine gas, and chlorinated water which may occur within the facilities boundaries.
